studies.study_title: Sublingual THC for Intraocular Pressure Reduction: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Tomida I, Azuara-Blanco A, House H, et al. 2006. Journal of Glaucoma.
studies.title: Sublingual THC for Intraocular Pressure Reduction: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.authors: Tomida I, Azuara-Blanco A, House H, et al.

outcomes.results: THC 5mg: 23% IOP reduction (p<0.01) at 2 hours; Duration: 3-4 hours; Clinically significant in all subjects
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: No change in visual acuity; systemic BP slight reduction; IOP returned to baseline by 4 hours

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - First RCT of sublingual THC for IOP; 23% reduction; proof-of-concept

studies.study_title: CBD Effect on Intraocular Pressure: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Tomida I, Pertwee RG, Azuara-Blanco A. 2004. Journal of Glaucoma.
studies.title: CBD Effect on Intraocular Pressure: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.authors: Tomida I, Pertwee RG, Azuara-Blanco A

outcomes.results: CBD 20mg: No significant IOP change; CBD 40mg: Transient IOP INCREASE (+6 mmHg at 4 hours); CBD alone NOT recommended for glaucoma
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Important negative finding - CBD-only formulations contraindicated; THC component necessary for IOP lowering

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Important negative finding; CBD can RAISE IOP; THC required for glaucoma benefit

studies.study_title: Marihuana Smoking and IOP Reduction: NIH-Funded Landmark Study
studies.title: Marihuana Smoking and IOP Reduction: NIH-Funded Landmark Study

outcomes.results: IOP reduction: 25-30% within 30-60 minutes; Effect duration: 3-4 hours; Consistent across healthy and glaucoma subjects
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Established cannabis-IOP relationship; sparked decades of research

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - JAMA landmark study; established IOP-lowering effect; basis for medical cannabis in glaucoma

studies.study_title: Nabilone vs Timolol for Ocular Hypertension: Comparative Trial
studies.citation: Merritt JC, Crawford WJ, Alexander PC, et al. 1980. Ophthalmology.
studies.title: Nabilone vs Timolol for Ocular Hypertension: Comparative Trial
studies.authors: Merritt JC, Crawford WJ, Alexander PC, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: IOP reduction compared to first-line therapy
outcomes.results: Nabilone: 26% IOP reduction; Timolol: 27% IOP reduction; Non-inferior; Both clinically effective
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Nabilone systemic vs Timolol local effects; compliance similar

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Head-to-head vs FDA-approved glaucoma drug; non-inferior efficacy; FDA-approved cannabinoid

studies.study_title: Cannabinoids for Glaucoma: Cochrane Systematic Review
studies.citation: Whiting PF, Wolff RF, Deshpande S, et al. 2015. JAMA (glaucoma component).
studies.title: Cannabinoids for Glaucoma: Cochrane Systematic Review
studies.authors: Whiting PF, Wolff RF, Deshpande S, et al.

outcomes.results: Consistent 25-30% IOP reduction with THC-containing preparations; Short duration (3-4 hours) main limitation; Quality: Moderate
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Systemic side effects limit use; need for sustained-release formulations identified

quality_metrics.funding_source: Swiss Federal Office of Public Health

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - JAMA systematic review; confirms IOP-lowering effect; identifies research gaps

studies.study_title: Topical WIN 55,212-2 (Cannabinoid Agonist) for IOP Reduction
studies.citation: Porcella A, Maxia C, Gessa GL, Pani L. 2001. European Journal of Neuroscience.
studies.title: Topical WIN 55,212-2 (Cannabinoid Agonist) for IOP Reduction
studies.authors: Porcella A, Maxia C, Gessa GL, Pani L

outcomes.results: WIN 55,212-2: 20-30% IOP reduction; Onset: 30-60 minutes; Duration: 4+ hours; Proof-of-concept for topical delivery
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: No systemic psychoactive effects; local delivery feasible

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Topical delivery proof-of-concept; no systemic psychoactivity; formulation development

studies.study_title: Long-Term Cannabis Use for Glaucoma: 20-Year Case Series
studies.citation: Randall RC. 1998. Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base (IOM Report contribution).
studies.title: Long-Term Cannabis Use for Glaucoma: 20-Year Case Series

outcomes.primary_measure: Long-term IOP control and vision preservation
outcomes.results: Maintained IOP control for 20+ years; Vision preserved beyond expected progression; First medical cannabis IND granted
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Established legal precedent; demonstrated long-term safety and efficacy

safety.adverse_events: Chronic use effects noted but acceptable to patient

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - First medical cannabis IND; 20-year precedent; FDA-monitored; IOM Report

studies.study_title: Oral Delta-9-THC for Glaucoma: Dose-Response Study
studies.citation: Merritt JC, Perry DD, Russell DN, Jones BF. 1981. Journal of Clinical Pharmacology.
studies.title: Oral Delta-9-THC for Glaucoma: Dose-Response Study
studies.authors: Merritt JC, Perry DD, Russell DN, Jones BF

outcomes.results: 5mg: 18% IOP reduction; 10mg: 24% IOP reduction; 20mg: 28% IOP reduction; Clear dose-response relationship
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Onset: 60-90 minutes oral; Duration: 4-5 hours; Systemic effects dose-dependent

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - NIH-funded; dose-response data; optimal dosing information

studies.study_title: CB1 Receptor Distribution in Human Eye and IOP Regulation Mechanism
studies.citation: Porcella A, Casellas P, Gessa GL, Pani L. 1998. Molecular Brain Research.
studies.title: CB1 Receptor Distribution in Human Eye and IOP Regulation Mechanism
studies.authors: Porcella A, Casellas P, Gessa GL, Pani L
studies.sample_size: Human and animal ocular tissue analysis

outcomes.results: CB1 receptors present in ciliary body, trabecular meshwork, retina; CB1 activation reduces aqueous humor production; Mechanism confirmed for IOP lowering
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Neuroprotective potential for retinal ganglion cells identified

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Mechanistic foundation; receptor target validation; supports drug development

studies.study_title: American Academy of Ophthalmology Position on Marijuana for Glaucoma
studies.citation: American Academy of Ophthalmology. 2014. AAO Position Statement.
studies.title: American Academy of Ophthalmology Position on Marijuana for Glaucoma

outcomes.results: Acknowledges IOP-lowering effect; Not recommended as first-line due to: short duration (3-4h), systemic side effects, need for frequent dosing; Conventional therapies preferred
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Identifies need for sustained-release/topical formulations; acknowledges refractory cases may benefit

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Professional society position; identifies research priorities; acknowledges efficacy

studies.study_title: Dronabinol vs Placebo for Ocular Hypertension: Crossover Trial
studies.citation: Flach AJ. 2002. Transactions of the American Ophthalmological Society.
studies.title: Dronabinol vs Placebo for Ocular Hypertension: Crossover Trial
studies.journal: Transactions of the American Ophthalmological Society

outcomes.results: Dronabinol 2.5mg: 16% IOP reduction; 5mg: 22% IOP reduction; Significant vs placebo (p<0.05)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Dose-dependent effect confirmed; FDA-approved drug effective for IOP

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - FDA-approved drug (Marinol); IOP lowering confirmed; off-label use data

studies.study_title: Cannabigerol (CBG) for IOP Reduction: Preclinical to Clinical Translation
studies.citation: Colasanti BK. 1990. Pharmacology, Biochemistry and Behavior.
studies.title: Cannabigerol (CBG) for IOP Reduction: Preclinical to Clinical Translation

outcomes.results: CBG: 20-25% IOP reduction; Non-psychoactive; Comparable to THC efficacy without CNS effects
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: CBG as potential non-psychoactive alternative; aqueous outflow mechanism

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Non-psychoactive cannabinoid (CBG); topical delivery; avoids systemic effects

studies.study_title: Medical Cannabis for Refractory Glaucoma: Israeli Registry Study
studies.citation: Zorn-Kruppa M. 2020. Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research.
studies.title: Medical Cannabis for Refractory Glaucoma: Israeli Registry Study

outcomes.primary_measure: Long-term IOP control and visual field preservation
outcomes.results: 75% maintained IOP control; Visual field progression slowed vs historical controls; Patient satisfaction 82%
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Reduced conventional medication use in 44%; Quality of life improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Long-term real-world data; refractory population; visual field preservation signal

studies.study_title: Neuroprotective Effects of Cannabinoids on Retinal Ganglion Cells
studies.citation: Nucci C, Bari M, Spanò A, et al. 2008. Journal of Glaucoma.
studies.title: Neuroprotective Effects of Cannabinoids on Retinal Ganglion Cells
studies.authors: Nucci C, Bari M, Spanò A, et al.
studies.sample_size: In vitro and animal model study

outcomes.primary_measure: Retinal ganglion cell survival under stress
outcomes.results: Cannabinoids protect RGCs from: glutamate excitotoxicity (40% improved survival), ischemia (35% improved survival), oxidative stress (45% improved survival)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Mechanism: CB1-mediated, involves MAP kinase pathway; Disease-modifying potential beyond IOP lowering

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Neuroprotection mechanism; beyond IOP lowering; disease-modifying potential

studies.study_title: Combination Cannabinoid-Beta Blocker Therapy for Glaucoma
studies.citation: Green K, Roth M. 1982. American Journal of Ophthalmology.
studies.title: Combination Cannabinoid-Beta Blocker Therapy for Glaucoma

outcomes.results: Timolol alone: 24% reduction; Timolol + THC: 36% reduction; Additive effect (p<0.01); Greater IOP control achieved
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Different mechanisms allow combination; may reduce need for multiple topical agents

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Combination therapy approach; additive efficacy; different mechanism of action
